abstract.p: In wireless sensor networks, location awareness along with the sensed data is important for most of the applications. Although there are many localization techniques in the literature, some of these techniques involve tiny sensor nodes, which need to be computationally powerful and complex in hardware to estimate their locations. This paper proposes a modified sectoral sweeper-based localization estimation (M-SSLE) method, which is the improved version of our previously studied SSLE method, to achieve position information of sensor nodes. This technique requires only a central node having a smart antenna capability to estimate locations of sensor nodes and simplified message formats. Using the SSLE technique, the computational burden for location estimation is carried out by a central node and no hardware or software modification to tiny sensor devices is required. The M-SSLE is implemented using an OPNET modeler for realistic fading channel conditions. The detailed implementation methodology in OPNET is presented in terms of node and process models. The performance of the M-SSLE method is evaluated through different network scenarios and channel parameters in terms of localization error, average throughput, and node energy consumption. Furthermore, its localization performance is compared with the SSLE and Cramér Rao Bound methods in the two different scenarios for the deployment of the sensor nodes. The M-SSLE average localization errors of 4.3 and 8.9 m are demonstrated under the log-distance and the log-normal shadowing channel conditions in a 250 m × 250 m area, respectively.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Wireless sensor networks (WSNs) handle a large number of wireless nodes to collect information from their sensing area.1 WSNs consist of a central node (CN) and a large number of spatially distributed sensor nodes (SNs). These tiny devices, which have limited battery and processing capability, usually communicate with the CN via multiple hops.2 Generally, the sink has more processing and memory capabilities than the SNs. In the literature, different kinds of WSN applications have been proposed. The location information of SNs is a basic requirement for most of these applications, since the sensing results without the location information cannot be applied for many WSN applications. The prevalent increase of using WSNs in diverse applications, such as military, wildlife, and agriculture, where they cannot be easily manageable and scalable steers the users to use more complex and efficient solutions for localization.3 Hand-operated deployment of SNs is not feasible for large-scale networks or inaccessible environments.4

Providing each sensor with localization hardware is expensive in terms of cost and energy consumption. A more reasonable solution to the localization problem in the large networks entails CNs to determine sensor location information, and allow other nodes to infer their information from multi-hop communication. These solutions are called centralized algorithms.5 Centralized algorithms generally use only one CN to determine all SNs’ location and produce a general map of the sensor network.6 These algorithms require the migration of inter-node ranging information and connectivity7 data at the CN and then the migration of resulting locations back to SNs.

Energy consumption, location estimation accuracy, implementation, and computation issues account for the major metrics in localization performance in WSNs.8 When considering these metrics, the centralized techniques are easy to design because the SNs do not require any hardware modification. The distributed algorithms are usually more energy-efficient than those of typical centralized ones, because each SN’s information is to be sent over multiple hops to a CN. Centralized algorithms require only the exchange of local information among neighboring nodes;9 therefore, they do not require more complex and powerful SNs as in the case of distributed algorithms.

While the topic of directional or smart antenna in WSNs is a well-known technique that is thoroughly described in the open literature, there are few papers dealing with localization schemes appropriate for WSNs and their specific objectives, requirements, and applications. In most of these studies, beacon nodes are assumed to be equipped with directional antennas.10 However, such an antenna on several beacon nodes increases the network complexity and cost efficiency. The smart antenna system (SAS) or directional antenna is a phased or adaptive antenna array. These systems combine multiple antenna elements with the high signal processing capability to optimize its antenna pattern automatically according to the wireless channel conditions.11 SASs have several advantages, such as effectively suppressing co-channel interference, increasing capacity, and extending coverage.12 In the literature, there are some hardware platforms to implement smart antenna capabilities on the CN.13,14 Besides, numerous studies have been proposed to decrease the energy constraints and to increase the overall system performance in WSNs using smart or directional antennas.12,15,16 In Hou et al.,15 single beam flow routing with directional antenna has been proposed, which is shown to extend the network lifetime. In Dunlop and Cortes,16 a Medium Access Control (MAC) protocol with a directional antenna has been proposed to consume less energy than its peer using an omnidirectional antenna.

The work of Cho et al.17 shows network lifetime improvements with a protocol that uses a directional antenna mounted only on the CN. In Elmusrati and Hasu18 and Ochiai et al.,19 a centralized antenna array with beamforming capabilities has been considered for efficient data transmission and positioning, hence decreasing the energy consumption and improving the system lifetime and performance in the WSN.

In Zhang and Yu,20 a mobile beacon node integrated with a directional antenna is used to determine the position of SNs, and a localization scheme called greatest gain direction line intersection (GGDI) is proposed to minimize the impact of the SNs. In GGDI, it is assumed that a mobile beacon follows a trail and transmits beacon messages in the sensor area. These beacon messages include the mobile beacon node’s position, a time indicator, and the beam width of the directional antenna. Each SN provides its location in a decentralized manner by using the geometric parameters of the desired area. The work of Worasawate et al.21 presents a simple switched beam antenna system for the localization system in WSNs. A beacon node is located indoor and transmits beacon messages. The anchor nodes have been placed at known positions and integrated with the switch beam antenna system. By localizing the SNs with an antenna array equipped on anchors, Kułakowski et al.10 have proposed a system concept based on angle of arrival (AOA) measurements. In this technique, rotating beacons are created by changing the direction of maximum radiation of the antenna array. Then, SNs determine the AOA when the beacon has the strongest power. Finally, the SNs estimate their locations by using a standard least square approach. An algorithm that uses a directional antenna on the SNs is proposed by Chaurasiya et al.22 In this algorithm, anchor nodes are placed at known positions. SNs collect the information from the other nodes and send it to a CN, which computes the positions of each SN. The limitations of this algorithm are that it cannot support mobile SNs and, also, the complexity of the algorithm and the volume of message traffic increases when the number of SNs increases. A distributed localization scheme, which is called the rectangle overlapping approach (ROA), proposed by Wu and Chen,23 can use a mobile beacon with a global positioning system (GPS) and a directional antenna. The mobile beacon tracks the specified pattern around the sensor area and broadcasts its position by a directional antenna. The locations of the tiny SNs can be calculated by simple operations according to the current position of the mobile beacon, including the angle and position information. The rotatable antenna localization (RAL) scheme proposed by Jiang et al.24 uses two beacon nodes with a directional antenna. These nodes broadcast beacon signals containing their location and antenna orientations. The orientation of the SNs with respect to the beacon nodes is computed by observing the variation of the received signal strength indicator (RSSI) values of the beacon signals. Each SN determines its own position with the computed orientations and the exact locations of two beacon nodes. In Lazos and Poovendran,25 a beacon node can rotate the antenna pattern and transmit beacon signals to the desired directions. Also, the communication range in the desired direction is controlled by adjusting the transmission power of beacon nodes. Each SN can then estimate its location by computing the overlap of the coverage areas.

The technique presented in this paper is called the modified sectoral sweeper-based localization estimation (M-SSLE) for WSN localization. The M-SSLE method is based on the previously proposed SSLE method.26 Compared to a previously reported technique (SSLE), this proposed method requires simplified message format and elimination of the transmission of additional antenna beams, and shows performance improvement on the localization accuracy. This technique can be classified as a centralized technique, because it involves only a CN to determine the location of the SNs. The CN can transmit messages to the sensing region with the desired direction and range by setting the direction, beamwidth, and transmit power level of the routing beam. It broadcasts sequential downlink messages via desired parameters through the SNs. The SNs do not require any additional modification on their hardware or software in this technique. They can operate in different modes27 and use the multi-hop communication in the forward link. The modified version of the SSLE is implemented by the OPNET modeler28 under the real channel fading conditions. Following that, the localization performance of the M-SSLE method is compared to the existing SSLE and the Cramér Rao Bound (CRB) methods.29 The CRB method can be used as the lower bound on the accuracy of localization of the SNs in a WSN.
The main contributions of this paper can be listed as follows.

list-item.p: It presents the M-SSLE technique based on the SSLE technique for location estimation with a smart antenna in WSNs.

It shows that the proposed technique provides around 30–40% localization performance improvement compared to its previous version under the realistic simulation parameters. While using the narrower beamwidth, it shows very close results to the Cramér Rao lower bound.

It presents that, since energy consumption is one of the important metrics in WSNs, each SN’s energy sensitivity in the M-SSLE method is more effective than in the SSLE method. The M-SSLE method provides almost 30% energy saving under the log-normal shadowing effects.
It provides the detailed OPNET modeler-based implementation of the M-SSLE method for realistic channel fading conditions.
Using the OPNET simulation results, it analyzes the effects of the network and channel parameters on the performance of the M-SSLE scheme.
Based on our performance evaluation, it shows the effectiveness of our M-SSLE technique and robustness against varying channel conditions.

sec.p: The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, the SSLE method is briefly introduced. Section 3 presents the details of the M-SSLE technique, algorithms that are running at the CNs and SNs, and a timing diagram. The implementation methodology of the M-SSLE method in the OPNET modeler with node and process models is presented in Section 4. Section 5 discusses the performance evaluation under different propagation conditions in terms of location accuracy, energy consumption, and throughput, and compares the results with those of the SSLE and CRB methods. Finally, Section 6 concludes the paper.

sec.title: 2. Sectoral sweeper-based localization estimation technique
sec.p: The SSLE technique was proposed as a localization technique using the sectoral sweeping approach through the sensing area.26 It requires only one CN to determine SNs’ locations. In this technique, the CN is to be integrated with a SAS, which has array signal processing capabilities. The SNs have a traditional omnidirectional antenna. While the CN uses broadcasting communication in the downlink, SNs employ multi-hop communication in the reverse link. The SSLE technique is based on two-dimensional sweeping, azimuth and radial. The CN can perform the azimuth and range sweeping process using its smart antenna capabilities. It can form the antenna patterns, called routing and task beams, to a desired direction and beamwidth. These antenna patterns switch the SNs into routing or active modes. Also, the CN can compute the RSSI values that are inserted in the system messages. The SSLE method can be considered as the application layer protocol that takes into account the physical layer propagation mechanism and it can be easily used by any other WSN protocol stack.30 In the range sweeping process, while the direction and beamwidth of the consecutive antenna transmissions are fixed, the power level of the transmission beams is increased step by step, which is indicated by RSSI levels in the downlink messages. In the azimuth sweeping, while RSSI levels are fixed, the direction of the transmission beams is changed step by step. The CN waits for response messages from the SNs via multi-hop communication during each increment of the transmission beam and keeps these messages in its database. At the end of the sweeping process, the SSLE method uses the angle estimation and range estimation algorithms (REAs) to locate the SNs.

sec.title: 3. The modified sectoral sweeper-based localization estimation technique
sec.p: Figure 1 shows the flowchart of the localization process in the M-SSLE technique for both the CN and SNs. Initially, the CN with smart antenna capabilities sets the required parameters, that is, i = 1, j = 1, α(i,j), Δθ, ΔR, and Δφ, where i and j are the level index of the transmit power and azimuth direction, respectively. α is the direction of the transmission beam, and Δθ and ΔR are increment levels for the direction and range of the routing beam, respectively. Δφ is the beamwidth of the transmission beam, which depends on the number of antenna elements (M). RSSImin and RSSImax values to be determined for the current routing beam are related to transmit power (PT) of the CN and path loss (PL) of the wireless channel conditions.

caption.p: The modified sectoral sweeper-based localization estimation algorithm: (a) central node process; (b) sensor node process.

sec.p: After these initialization steps, it is checked whether the maximum range and maximum direction of the routing beam remains within the targeted sensor field. Regarding the SNs’ process, they stay in the idle mode for a short period of time and then turn their radios off for the sleeping period. They keep their radio continuously on, upon receiving REQUEST messages from the CN. The CN broadcasts the REQUEST packets via the routing beam, which includes Sector_no, RSSImin and RSSImax. The SNs that receive this REQUEST message from the CN determine their receive (RX) power level. If it is within the threshold indicated by the REQUEST, the nodes switch into active mode and generate RESPONSE packets, including their node_ID. The nodes whose RX power level is not within the threshold indicated by RSSImin and RSSImax do not generate RESPONSE packets, but switch into routing mode. Hence, RESPONSE packets generated by active mode nodes are transmitted towards the CN via multi-hop communication through active and routing nodes. The CN extracts required parameters from captured RESPONSE messages and saves them in a database for further processing to obtain the location of the SNs.

After a sufficient number of RESPONSE messages are gathered from the valid routing region, the CN increments the beam direction to the next level for the azimuth sweeping process, while keeping the same RSSI values as in the previous beam direction. This azimuth process is continued until the direction of the routing beam remains within the targeted azimuth region, that is, α(i,j) ≤θmax. Then, the above procedure for azimuth sweeping is repeated for the next range level by setting the power level to the next highest level. The overall sweeping procedure ends when RSSImin≤dmax, where dmax is the received power level corresponding to the maximum range of the routing beam in the sensor area. At the end of the two-stage sweeping process, the angle estimation algorithm (AEA)26 and updated REA are run to estimate the location of the SNs. Compared to previous REA, the updated REA accomplishes range estimation more precisely under the shadowing effect in the sensing area. The updated REA considers consecutive range increments. If there is a missing response message between the i and i+2th range levels, it only uses the ith range level to determine the range estimation.

A distinction of the M-SSLE method from the previously proposed SSLE method is the use of simplified message formats. Although the previously proposed SSLE method generates messages to switch the sensor modes, the M-SSLE method sets up some interrupts on the SNs to switch different modes. Thus, the overall network traffic is decreased, as is the energy consumption in the SNs. The M-SSLE method generates two different types of messages. This modified technique uses the REQUEST messages, which are generated by the CN, and RESPONSE messages generated by the SNs. The timing scheme and message traffic between the CN and SNs are illustrated in Figure 2. The CN and SNs are involved in all localization process during the time of the Tsweep. The M-SSLE method uses only routing beams, while the SSLE method uses the transmission of the active and the routing beams. The SNs are run in active or route modes by these beams. While the SNs only route the received messages in the routing mode, the active nodes in the active mode involve a certain event, generate a packet, and route the packets. When using only routing beam, the M-SSLE method simplifies timing synchronization and reduces the processing load at the CN. The CN generates routing beams and transmits periodic messages to the desired part of the whole network. The time interval between two routing beams transmitted by the CN is represented by Tcn_wait. Time synchronization and calibration in WSNs are beyond the scope of this paper, since available techniques and algorithms for synchronization exist in the literature.31,32 We consider that time synchronization and calibration between SNs are assumed to be achieved. Also, the feasibility of the convenient calibration is studied in the literature.33 As a result of these studies, it can be said that the time synchronization and calibration error can degrade the localization performance between 100–10−4 m.31,34

caption.p: Timing scheme and message flow of the modified sectoral sweeper-based localization estimation technique and sensor nodes’ operating modes in this technique.

sec.p: It is assumed that both the CN and SNs use interrupts to determine the end of the relevant period. Initially, the CN broadcasts the REQUEST message via the first routing beam to the SNs, which are covered by this beam. These SNs receive the REQUEST message with the certain propagation delay. At the end of Tsn_listen, the SNs switch into active, route, or sleep operating modes during Tsn_mode. When the SNs stay in idle mode, they put their microcontroller unit (MCU) in power down mode and their radio unit in power up mode during the time of Tsn_listen. The SNs listen to the channel during this idle period. In the active mode, they generate RESPONSE packets and route other SNs’ packets for the localization process. The SNs keep their radio, MCU, and sensing unit on during the time of the active mode. The SNs in the route mode can only route the messages. Their radio and MCU units are power on, while their sensing unit is power off during this route period. In the sleep mode, the SNs put all their functional units in power down mode until their interrupts enable them to wake up and go into idle mode.

sec.title: 4. OPNET implementation of the modified sectoral sweeper-based localization estimation method
sec.p: OPNET implementation of the M-SSLE technique is divided into two complementary parts operating at the SNs and CN. In the following sections, their simulation models, which consist of network, node and process models, realized using the OPNET modeler are explained in detail.

sec.title: 4.1. Modeling the SN in the M-SSLE method
sec.p: The SN employing the M-SSLE method forwards its identity information to the CN using a multi-hop approach. In the simulation model, the SN performs two tasks. Firstly, it produces a RESPONSE packet upon receiving a REQUEST packet transmitted from the CN. Secondly, it forwards the RESPONSE packet via neighboring SNs. The SNs use the RESPONSE packet structure illustrated in Figure 3. A RESPONSE packet necessarily consists of Terminal_ID and Virtual_Terminal_ID fields. It can also include a data field when required, depending on the state of the networking application. The latter includes necessary information used by the CN for location estimation, while the former is used to prevent system overflow resulting from the SNs continuously sending duplicate messages to their neighbors.

In the node model of the SN, the standard WSN protocol stack is used for the protocol layers.1 Existing MAC protocols can be used in this model. The model does not require changing the MAC protocol. The model also uses a standard receiver, transmitter, and an antenna module for the physical layer interface between the node module and wireless channel. Figure 4 shows the SNs’ process model designed by using the OPNET modeler.

caption.p: Process model of the sensor nodes.

sec.p: In this process model, the process starts with the “init” state indicated by the bold arrow. The systems variables are defined and their first values are loaded. Then the process enters the “idle” state and waits here until a specific interrupt arrives. The “receiver” state machine obtains the received signal power of the packet arriving at the SN. If the received packet is a REQUEST packet, the “receiver” state machine checks out its signal power then realizes the process either by inserting this packet into the look-up table or creating a RESPONSE packet. If the received packet is a RESPONSE packet and not the SN’s own packet, the “receiver” state machine checks out the Terminal_ID of the packet from the look-up table then, accordingly, the packet is either destroyed or inserted into the queue. The “slotTime” state machine sends the packets in the queue to the CN and sets up an interrupt for the SN’s next slot time. The “sleep” state machine turns the radio off for Tsn_mode then waits for an interrupt. All of these SN process model state machine functions are presented in Figure 5.

sec.title: 4.2. Modeling the CN in the M-SSLE method
sec.p: The CN realizes the process both by steering the antenna beam and broadcasting the REQUEST packet, whose structure is illustrated in Figure 6. The SN receiving the REQUEST packet runs either in the route mode or the active mode, depending on the RSSI of the packet and power levels indicated in the RSSImax and RSSImin fields. After that the SN returns a RESPONSE packet to the CN, then it saves the Terminal_IDs of the nodes responding to REQUEST packet.

The node model of the CN with smart antenna capabilities is responsible for all layer requirements, including RX-TX and smart antenna modules, for the physical layer interface between the node and wireless channel. The smart antenna module includes predefined and adaptive beams. In this work, we implement predefined individual beams and each beam covers a specific overlapping region in the sensor area. Antenna patterns are assumed to have a conical shape for transceiving in the desired region. The CN process model designed using the OPNET modeler is illustrated in Figure 7.

caption.p: Process model of the central node.

sec.p: The CN process model starts with the “init” state. It then enters the “beamSteer” state that sets up an interrupt to steer the beam direction. Further, it waits in the “idle” state until a specific interrupt arrives. The “directAntenna” state machine steers the antenna to a desired direction for a specific time (Tcn_wait) interval using the predefined parameters. The “receiver” state machine gets the RESPONSE packets, extracts the location estimation information (e.g., Terminal_ID), and then stores it in the CN database. The flowchart for the CN process model with all functions is presented in Figure 8.

caption.p: The central node process model algorithm.

sec.title: 5. Performance evaluation using OPNET
sec.p: In this section, we evaluate the performance of the M-SSLE method through simulation. We have implemented our localization technique under IEEE 802.15.4 coordinated distributed scheduling in the OPNET network simulator. This technique is analyzed in terms of localization error, energy consumption, and throughput. The performance of the localization error is compared with existing SSLE and CRB methods. MICAz platform specifications35 used in our experiments are in accordance with the CN. These values of the parameters are shown in Table 1. Initially, each SN is forced to stay in idle mode when starting the localization process. We consider two different topologies in our experiments, as depicted in Figure 9, and vary the number of SNs in the network to investigate the localization performance of all three techniques. The diameter of the cluster that constructs the network topology has been chosen as 250 m. There are 120 SNs and a single CN in grid deployment topology, while there are 100 SNs and a single CN in random topology. In random topology, the SNs are uniformly distributed over the simulation environment. While the CN is equipped with a smart antenna, each SN is equipped with an omnidirectional antenna.

caption.p: Specifications of the central and sensor nodes.
A snapshot of wireless sensor network scenarios implemented in the OPNET modeler: (a) grid deployment; (b) random deployment.

sec.p: In the simulation model, the CN can steer the antenna beam constructed using specified Δθ and Δφ parameters. Then, it broadcasts a REQUEST packet, including the RSSImin and RSSImax information obtained for this region. In response, the SNs send their own RESPONSE packets to the CN. In both scenarios, time division multiple access (TDMA) as a MAC technique36 and flooding2 as a routing protocol are used. The flooding protocol forwards incoming packets to neighboring SNs without checking out the packets’ content.2 For this reason, the network experiences an undesired overloaded situation and its operation may severely slow down. In order to prevent this bottleneck, we use the flooding algorithm, in which a look-up table is formed at each SN. Terminal_IDs of the received packets are stored in the look-up table. By matching the Terminal_IDs of the received packets with the ones that are already stored in the look-up table, any redundant transfer of a RESPONSE packet belonging to the same node is avoided.

As a wireless channel model, three path loss conditions are considered: the log-distance path loss model (referred to as Path 1); the log-normal shadowing path loss model with Xσ = 5 dB (referred to as Path 2); and the log-normal shadowing path loss model with Xσ = 7 dB (referred to as Path 3). Xσ is the standard deviation of the log-normal shadowing. The path loss exponent is chosen as 2.8 for the rural environment at 2.4 GHz. The simulation parameters used are listed in Table 2. The antenna pattern editor of the OPNET modeler has been used for building the antenna pattern in the simulation models. Five different antenna patterns are used for the routing beam in this work. These patterns have a conical shape with beamwidths (Δφ) of 5°, 10°, 15°, 20°, and 25° and gain of 10 dBi for the main beam and –20 dBi for the side beams. SNs have an isotropic antenna with antenna gain of approximately 0 dBi.13 Sample antenna patterns are illustrated in Figure 10. The direction and beamwidth of antenna beams can be dynamically adjusted for different sweeper conditions by the CN. Transmit power levels are determined according to log-distance and log-normal shadowing path loss.37 The signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and signal-to-interference ratio (SIR) levels in the wireless channel are set as –30 and –20 dB below the related transmit power level of the CN.

fn.p: CN: central node; SN: sensor node; SNR: signal-to-noise ratio; SIR: signal-to-interference ratio.

sec.title: 5.1. Localization performance of the M-SSLE method
sec.p: In the M-SSLE method, the locations of the SNs are computed based on the number of the received RESPONSE messages from SNs by the CN. The beamwidth and transmission power determine the coverage area of the CN. Therefore, they affect the number of received RESPONSE messages and the localization error. The way of analyzing the simulation results is to examine the average localization performance. The comparative localization error performance of the grid and random topologies is summarized in Figures 11 and 12, where the beamwidth varies between 5° and 25°. As shown in Figure 11, the average localization error for grid topology decreases for all three channel conditions when the beamwidth of the routing beam narrows. When the same channel condition is considered, the narrow sweeping increment provides lesser localization error. The average localization error is considered the same for Path 1 in the M-SSLE and SSLE methods. Furthermore, the M-SSLE and SSLE methods have 11.6–14 m and 17–25 m average localization errors for Path 2 and Δθ = 5°, respectively. In Path 3, the average error of the M-SSLE method decreases to 12.1–13 m for Δθ = 3°. When the beamwidth is increased, the average error becomes stationary for the CRB method. The performance of the average localization error becomes closer to the CRB method with the narrow beamwidth, which means that the accuracy of the localization is improved.

caption.p: Average localization error performance comparison of existing schemes (sectoral sweeper-based localization estimation (SSLE) and Cramér Rao Bound (CRB)) and the modified sectoral sweeper-based localization estimation (M-SSLE) method for the grid deployment and various path loss models.

Average localization error performance comparison of existing schemes (sectoral sweeper-based localization estimation (SSLE) and Cramér Rao Bound (CRB)) and the modified sectoral sweeper-based localization estimation (M-SSLE) method for the random deployment and various path loss models.

sec.p: When random deployment of SNs is considered, the average localization error also decreases as the beamwidth of the routing beam narrows, as shown in Figure 12. Almost the same comments as in the grid deployment can be made regarding the effect of beamwidth in random deployment. While the smallest average localization error is approximately 4.2 m for the channel condition with log-distance path loss model in Figure 12(f), the largest average localization error gets up to 15 m for the channel condition with log-normal shadowing with 7 dB standard deviation in Figure 12(a). These results show that the improvement in localization performance is approximately 30–40% if the M-SSLE method is run in the sensor area. The localization error performance of the M-SSLE technique gets better, while the path loss effects decrease.

sec.title: 5.2. Throughput performance of the M-SSLE method
sec.p: In the M-SSLE localization technique, the number of message packets needed for localization determines the WSN energy consumption. Hence, it is important to control and reduce the message traffic and the number of packets. The number of RESPONSE and REQUEST packets used for WSN localization provides energy consumption information for each SNs. In the OPNET simulation model, each SN has a counter to determine the number of received packets. When the simulation ends, the average throughput can be computed by summing the counters for all SNs and then dividing it by the number of SNs in the network. The average number of required messages tabulated with respect to beamwidth for grid and random topology is given in Tables 3 and 4, respectively. The antenna beamwidth is varied from 5° to 25° for different path loss models. For both grid and random deployment, the average throughput is affected by different channel conditions. As expected for both deployments, the average throughput decreases as the channel conditions get worse. The narrower the sweeping increment in azimuth, the larger the throughput is. The average throughput difference between Δθ = 5° and Δθ = 3° decreases as the beamwidth is reduced. In other words, the average throughput is not affected that much with changing sweeping increments when the routing beamwidth is small. We observe that the average throughput performance of the modified SSLE method is slightly better for random deployment of the nodes.

caption.p: Average throughput for the grid deployment of sensor nodes when the modified sectoral sweeper-based localization estimation model is applied for different sweeping parameters and various path loss models.

Average throughput for the random deployment of sensor nodes when the modified sectoral sweeper-based localization estimation model is applied for different sweeping parameters and various path loss models.

sec.title: 5.3. Node energy consumption performance of the M-SSLE method
sec.p: In WSN applications, energy consumption is one of the key factors to be considered for tiny SNs. Energy consumption of the nth node can be calculated using

where B is the message size, R is the data rate of the transceiver of a SN, and IRX and ITX are the current draw of the receive mode and the transmit mode.

The foremost energy consumption is due to transmitted and received messages, because the transceiver uses more than approximately 1000 times the current draw in the TX or RX modes than in the idle mode. The energy consumption due to switching modes and computation is small and can be ignored. Localization estimation accuracy of the SNs requires a sufficient number of received RESPONSE messages from the nodes. Figure 13 shows the comparison of the average energy consumption of the nodes under different path loss models and beamwidth in the grid topology. The modified SSLE with the wider beamwidth requires much more energy consumption compared to the narrower beamwidth. For example, in Figure 13, when Δφ is 25° for Path 3, each SN has consumed approximately 21 mJ for Δθ = 3° and 12 mJ for Δθ = 5°. When Δφ decreases to 5°, the average energy consumption at each SN is 3.1 mJ for Δθ = 3° and 2.5 mJ for Δθ = 5°. Beamwidth reduction of five times causes nearly 84% decrease in the energy consumption.

caption.p: Average energy consumption for the grid deployment of sensor nodes when the modified sectoral sweeper-based localization estimation method is applied for different sweeping parameters and various path loss models.

sec.p: The energy map of a sensor network in the grid deployment scenario as a gray-level image is presented in Figure 14, in which light shaded areas represent regions with more energy-consuming nodes. Using the energy map, network lifetime may be determined if any part of the sensor network is about to suffer from system failures in the near future due to depleted energy. As shown in Figures 14(a) and 14(b), SNs placed on the diagonal consume more energy than other nodes. The energy consumption gap is more for the wider beamwidth routing beam; this can be observed from Figure 14(b).

caption.p: Example of an energy map of a wireless sensor network scanned by the modified sectoral sweeper-based localization estimation method: (a) Δθ = 5° and Δφ = 5° and Path 1; (b) Δθ = 5° and Δφ = 25° and Path 1.

sec.p: For comparison, the average energy consumption for the different channel conditions and antenna beamwidth is considered for both the M-SSLE and SSLE methods in the random deployment. The simulation results are shown in Figure 15. Basically, the M-SSLE method with the wider beamwidth requires more energy consumption than the narrower beamwidth, which is due to the fact that for a wider beamwidth each node needs to use more message packets, thereby resulting in overheads. The M-SSLE technique performs better than its previous version in terms of energy consumption. In particular, when Δφ is 25° for Path 2, each SN has consumed approximately 25.1 mJ for Δθ = 3° and 15.5 mJ for Δθ = 5°. When Δφ is reduced to 5°, the average energy consumption on each SN is 3.8 mJ for Δθ = 3° and 2.1 mJ for Δθ = 5°. The M-SSLE method can gain around 10–28% performance improvement under those situations. Depending on the energy requirement of the WSN, parameters of the modified SSLE can be adjusted, and this appears as one of the advantages of the SSLE technique. Allowing for the CN node capabilities in the M-SSLE method, the performance improvement is considerable as compared with the SSLE method.

caption.p: Comparative energy-consuming performance for the random deployment of sensor nodes when the modified sectoral sweeper-based localization estimation (M-SSLE) and SSLE are applied for different sweeping parameters and various path loss models.

sec.title: 6. Conclusion
sec.p: We have proposed a centralized localization scheme, called the M-SSLE method, that allows the CN to determine the SNs’ position with smart antenna capabilities in different propagation conditions. The scheduling algorithms and timing scheme with the operating modes in this technique are given for the CN and SN. The M-SSLE method has also been modeled and simulated using OPNET modeler software for realistic channel conditions and packet flow in the network. OPNET implementation of processes running at the CN and the SN has been given in detail. Furthermore, we have considered the effects of various channel propagation conditions, that is, log-distance and log-normal shadowing path loss models, on the localization performance of the M-SSLE technique. The M-SSLE method allows robust localization even in the presence of shadowing effects in the channel. According to the simulation results of the M-SSLE method, which are verified by OPNET simulation software, the average localization error always get 8% lower for all conditions, and the average energy consuming may reduce 2.1 mJ. The use of the M-SSLE method in a WSN application with multiple CNs and its effect on mobility issues will be the subject of further research.

bio.title: Author biographies
bio.p: Kerem Kucuk is an assistant professor in the Wireless Communications and Information Systems (WINS) Research Center at Kocaeli University, Kocaeli, Turkey. He received his BS, MS, and PhD degrees from the Electronics and Computer Education Department at Kocaeli University. He was also a guest researcher and a visiting scholar at the Twente University, Pervasive Systems Group, Twente, the Netherlands, and the Wireless Information Systems Laboratory, University of Texas at Dallas, TX, USA. He is currently interested in wireless networks, ultra wideband systems, wireless local area network (WLAN) receiver design, and real-time signal processing.

Necla Bandirmali is an assistant professor in the Computer Engineering Department at Yalova University, Yalova, Turkey. She received her BS, MS, and PhD degrees from the Electronics and Computer Education Department at Kocaeli University. She was also a guest researcher and a visiting scholar at the Twente University, Pervasive Systems Group, Twente, the Netherlands, and the Wireless Information Systems Laboratory, University of Texas at Dallas, TX, USA. Her active research interests are security in wireless communications, WSNs and MAC protocols, and wireless communication.

Adnan Kavak received his BS degree from the Electrical and Electronics Engineering Department, Middle East Technical University, Ankara, Turkey. He received his MS and PhD degrees from the Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, The University of Texas at Austin, TX, USA, in 1996 and 2000, respectively. He worked as senior research engineer at Samsung Telecommunications America between 2000 and 2001. In the 2008–2009 academic year, he worked as a visiting associate professor at the Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, The University of Texas at Austin. He is currently a full professor at the Computer Engineering Department and the director of WINS Research Center at Kocaeli University, Turkey. His current research interests include mobile application and computing, WSNs and applications, multi-input, multi-output (MIMO) systems, resource allocation in 3G, and beyond networks.

Sedat Atmaca received his PhD degree from Kocaeli University, Turkey, in 2009. His active research interests include wireless communications, smart antennas, WSNs, high-speed communication protocols, cognitive radio networks, and modeling and simulation of telecommunications networks.
